user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_data:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_data (size_t size,
                               void *data,
                               int must_free,
                               int must_copy)
{
  enum MHD_ResponseMemoryMode mode;

  if (0 != must_copy)
    mode = MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_COPY;
  else if (0 != must_free)
    mode = MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_FREE;
  else
    mode = MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT;

  return MHD_create_response_from_buffer (size, data, mode);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_create_response_from_data:
enum MHD_ResponseMemoryMode
{

  /**
   * Buffer is a persistent (static/global) buffer that won't change
   * for at least the lifetime of the response, MHD should just use
   * it, not free it, not copy it, just keep an alias to it.
   * @ingroup response
   */
  MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT,

  /**
   * Buffer is heap-allocated with `malloc()` (or equivalent) and
   * should be freed by MHD after processing the response has
   * concluded (response reference counter reaches zero).
   * The more portable way to automatically free the buffer is function
   * MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback() with '&free' as
   * crfc parameter as it does not require to use the same runtime library.
   * @warning It is critical to make sure that the same C-runtime library
   *          is used by both application and MHD (especially
   *          important for W32).
   * @ingroup response
   */
  MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_FREE,

  /**
   * Buffer is in transient memory, but not on the heap (for example,
   * on the stack or non-`malloc()` allocated) and only valid during the
   * call to #MHD_create_response_from_buffer.  MHD must make its
   * own private copy of the data for processing.
   * @ingroup response
   */
  MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_COPY

}
...
int must_free
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code fragments were identified in the provided function. Reasoning: (1) The conditional chain (if (0 != must_copy) / else if (0 != must_free) / else ...) is not statically constant — each branch is reachable depending on the runtime values of the parameters, so none of those branches is inherently unreachable. (2) There is no code after the final return, no unreachable labels, and no switch/case fall-throughs or constant conditions present in the submitted snippets. (3) The enum definitions are ordinary symbol declarations and do not introduce unreachable code. (4) The stray 'int must_free' shown in the additional snippet appears to be an incomplete or separate declaration (not code that would be unreachable within the shown function) and does not by itself create unreachable code. If any of the involved identifiers (must_copy or must_free) are replaced by compile-time constant expressions elsewhere in the project, then that could create unreachable branches — that would require examination of the broader project build and preprocessor configuration, but based on the provided code alone there is no unreachable code to investigate.
